The DBS (Disclosure and Barring Service) has replaced the Criminal Records Bureau (CRB) and Independent Safeguarding Authority (ISA). It's barred list helps employers to make informed recruitment decisions and prevent unsuitable people from working with children and other vulnerable groups. The DBS processes requests for criminal records checks and decides who should be placed or removed from the DBS children's barred list, and adult's barred list for England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

The DBS is an executive non-departmental public body, sponsored by the Home Office.

The Mental Health Act 2007 is an Act of the Parliament which applies to people in England and Wales. It covers the reception, care and treatment of mentally disordered persons, the management of their property and other related matters. In particular, it provides the legislation by which people diagnosed with a mental disorder can be detained in hospital or police custody and have their disorder assessed or treated against their wishes. Its use is reviewed and regulated by the Care Quality Commission.

Life sustaining treatment is classed as medical treatment which would prolong your life without curing the underlying conditions. It can, in some instances, take the place of vital body functions and includes such things as; Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), Machine intervention, i.e. artificial or mechanical ventilation, Antibiotics, Transfusions, Nutrition and hydration, Dialysis, Chemotherapy or radiotherapy, Drugs, Therapies and Medical procedures.

Is also known as MCA and is an Act of the Parliament applying to England and Wales. Its sets out a legal framework for acting and making decisions on behalf of a person who lacks the capacity to make particular decisions for themselves.
